comment.author: 74004041@N06
comment._content: They certainly took security very seriously in those days!. I like those security doors.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06] The photo was taken in about 1949 - "Country Quiz" advertised on the entry barrier was a half-hour program running on the Macquarie Radio Network in the late 1940s. See Trove clipping which reports the program being recorded in Burnie Tasmania. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/69351322. Also note that passengers for East Hills and Illawarra lines had to change at Central. Note also the tram entry on the extreme right.

comment.author: 28304000@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] The reason why East Hills and Illawarra line passengers had to change at Central is because Circular Quay station had not been completed yet.  The City Circle was two sections at this point in time:  Central-St James and Central-Wynyard.  Train to the Illawarra and East Hills lines ran out of St James station.

comment.author: 28304000@N00
comment._content: Other points of interest:  Rookwood Station, Kurrajong Line and Dunheved Line are shown.

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/albert3801] Unbelievable, a broken circle for so long!

It makes perfect sense though with the Cahill expressway being built in the early 60s

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: If they are travelling at 11:35 ,  they are probably not "commuters"
